sub_topic: Calculation of entropy change for a chemical reaction
message_1:
What is the standard molar entropy change for the following reaction at 298 K? 
H2(g) + O2(g) → H2O(l) 

Given data: 
ΔH°f[H2O(l)] = -286 kJ/mol 
S°[H2(g)] = 130.7 J/mol K 
S°[O2(g)] = 205.0 J/mol K 
S°[H2O(l)] = 69.9 J/mol K
message_2:
To find the standard molar entropy change (ΔS°) for the reaction, we need to subtract the sum of the entropies of the reactants from the sum of the entropies of the products:

ΔS° = ΣS°(products) - ΣS°(reactants)

For the given reaction, H2(g) + O2(g) → H2O(l), the entropies of the reactants and products are given as:

S°[H2(g)] = 130.7 J/mol K
S°[O2(g)] = 205.0 J/mol K
S°[H2O(l)] = 69.9 J/mol K

Now, we can calculate the standard molar entropy change:

ΔS° = S°[H2O(l)] - (S°[H2(g)] + S°[O2(g)])
ΔS° = 69.9 J/mol K - (130.7 J/mol K + 205.0 J/mol K)
ΔS° = 69.9 J/mol K - 335.7 J/mol K
ΔS° = -265.8 J/mol K

So, the standard molar entropy change for the reaction at 298 K is -265.8 J/mol K.
